Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal ID: 0916828
PI name: Blanton Shawn
Institution: Carnegie-Mellon University
Title: Achieving IC Quality through On-Going Diagnosis and Customized Test

ABSTRACT
The main objective of computer chip testing has and continues to be the separation of good chips from bad ones (i.e., ones that do not meet the desired operational characteristics). Test is now however being expanded as a value-added endeavor. In this project, we are data-mining test data in order to continuously monitor chip quality. We propose to use diagnosis-extracted models of chip failures along with a new technique for estimating chip quality. Both are incorporated in an on-line, quality-monitoring methodology that ensures a desired level of quality by changing the actual tests applied to a computer chip to better match the characteristics of currently-failing chips.

This approach to quality is dynamic in nature and is a radical change from the typical approach. Without exception, each chip manufacturer (Intel, IBM, etc.) assumes that any type of defect can occur anywhere within their chip which means that each manufactured instance has to be thoroughly tested at considerable expense. This is akin to prescribing drugs for all possible diseases/ailments for every patient without performing one diagnostic examination. Opposed to the traditional approach, this proposed work instead diagnoses chips that have failed in the past to determine what ?diseases? (i.e., defects) actually are occurring within the fabricated ICs. The ?prescriptions? (i.e., the tests applied to the chips) can therefore be changed and/or minimized to match the diseases found instead of over-testing as is done now, leading to improved chip quality at minimal cost.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electronic systems are ubiquitous in our lives and are becoming increasingly used in systems (automobiles, medical devices, etc.) that affect our health and safety. New technologies for implementing electronics is expected to become less reliable so it is imperative that new design methodologies be developed to ensure that the systems built from emerging electronics are safe and resilient to failure. In this NSF-supported project, techniques that enable electronic systems to test themselves and localize identified failures have been developed and analyzed. The developed approach is economical in that it re-uses much of the same techniques used to test electronics at the time they are fabricated. This means that current producers of electronics (e.g., IBM, Texas Instruments, Intel, Qualcomm, etc.) can easily incorporate the test-and-diagnosis approach developed in this project into their future designs of electronic systems.

Both undergraduate and graduate students participated in this project, specifically being trained to both analyze and design advanced electronic systems using the state-of-the-art tools and fabrication technologies. One graduate student is now employed by a US-based company, and the undergraduate students are now planning to extend their education by seeking advanced (M.S. and Ph.D.) engineering degrees. The research conducted during this project has also led to new projects that will continue to further the advancement of electronic systems.
